div.head: Preface.
From The Lyceum Playbill.
div.p: "The dramatic form of composition, more than any other, demands completeness; and it is not with an idea of appending explanation to the picture he has endeavoured to paint, that the writer of the play now presented offers the following extract from an historical work. But in illustration of the state of society in the Isle of France, previously to its becoming a British possession, a few lines from Mr. Pridham's valuable and interesting history of "England's Colonial Empire," may be acceptable, as justifying whatever use the dramatist has made of the recorded prejudices and antipathies of the various classes of residents in the Island:—
"The Creole part of the population made themselves remarkable by the intrepidity they displayed on board the fleets of France, or by the efforts of individual enterprise."
"But the European looked with disdain upon the Creole, who, in turn, regarded the former as an adventurer."
"The Islanders were held in contempt by the poor noblesse of Mauritius, on account of their ignoble extraction."

"It was remarked also, that towards the latter end of the century, the French inhabitants of Mauritius appeared neither independent in their circumstances, nor easy in their minds, though they affected dress and gaiety."

"The condition of the Slave was that of the lowest and most abject degradation. Numbers of these unfortunates had European blood in their veins, being the offspring of liaisons between the Planters and their Slaves, but such a pedigree only increased their misfortune."

The unqualified success of this drama, and the kindness with which it has been treated by the whole press, leave the writer nothing to add, except an expression
of his acknowledgments to the artists who have so admirably interpreted his ideas. He has so often had the pleasure of entrusting a drama to the energetic and intelligent management of the Lyceum Theatre, and of witnessing the most satisfactory result, that he has long ceased to have any "first-night" apprehensions, except in regard to his own share in a new production. But well as he had appreciated the intellectual power and artistic skill of the company, the author of "The Creole" had not been prepared for the complete and finished portrait which every performer in the cast contributed to the general effect of the first representation. Something is always allowed, upon such an occasion, for haste, for nervousness, for inexperience in the full bearing and proportion of character; but at the production of the following play no such allowance was needed. To use the words of the journal under the direction of the first dramatist of the day— "Never did a piece of the kind play more completely on the first night. The three acts went, not only swiftly, but with all their variety of involution, smoothly as a ballet." "Douglas Jerrold's Weekly Newspaper."

It is not to any unusual number of rehearsals (there were, indeed, but six) that this completeness was attributable ; but to the indefatigable exertions of the actors, to all of whom the author begs to express his most sincere thanks, coupled with as sincere a regret that uncontradicted rumour assigns an early termination to the present prosperous management of the theatre. Where all was so admirable, it would be pleasant and easy to bear an appropriate tribute in each case; but this has been so ably done by the various gentlemen connected with the public Journals, that the author prefers leaving it in their hands. He cannot, however,
deny himself the gratification of saying how much he owes to Mrs. Keeley's exquisite personation of the fiery, reckless, kind-hearted Vivandière. The character is a difficult one—more difficult to a first-rate, than to an inferior performer—but its mixed impulses, and double audacities of habit and of heart, are all inimitably given by this accomplished artist.

The author may add—but by no means as matter of boast—that Mrs. Keeley's request that he would write her a play, was made on the morning of Tuesday, March the 16th, at which time one scene only of "The Creole" had been written, and that on the evening of the following Saturday, the completed drama (which is entirely original) was in the theatre.

div.stage: Scene 1.—The Scene represents a large open space, known as the "Place d'Armes." Port Louis, Mauritius. A lofty range of mountains in the distance, in some places grassy, in others topped by the projecting rocks. Houses at side, white, and interspersed with trees. As the curtain rises, distant cannon heard.
Enter Damiron and Virginie-

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Yes, – there she is, that's the vessel; do you see her, my dear, there ? (Virginie looks in the direction he indicates.) There she comes, with the troops we have expected so long. I confess to you, now that I see all's safe, that I sadly feared she had fallen into the hands of the English. Their cruisers keep us in constant hot water; one never knows when they will be down upon us. But why the deuce don't the fort answer her signal ?

div.stage: [Loud cannon, supposed to be on the island.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: How long will it be before they land ?

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Oh! not long, not long. I wonder where our young soldier is, by the bye. He ought to be on the spot to welcome his comrades.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: How little we see of Alphonse, papa.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p:
Ah! you have noticed that, have you? Yes, true enough, we do see very little of him, and, considering that we are his oldest acquaintances on the island, and considering that I was his father's most intimate friend for years before Master Alphonse de Nyon was born, and considering that when he came to take possession of his estate a month ago I gave him all sorts of information and assistance, and considering that my house cannot be called a dull one, seeing that I
am a very pleasant, amiable, lively old man, and that you are not a very disagreeable young woman, I think the gallant lieutenant might pay us the compliment of spending a little more time in our society.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Well, papa, you must excuse him for the present. It is a new thing to have a fine estate left to one, and a month is not a very long time to devote to visiting all its corners. If it were mine –

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Which I heartily hope it will be one of these fine days.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I should never be at rest until I knew every field, cottage, and garden, and every horse, and dog, and slave I had in the world.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: But he is never on his estate.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Not ?

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Never. For a day or two after he took possession all was well enough. But in the course of one of his rides he met with somebody—I don't know whom, mind, and, of course, I have no right to inquire—but he met with somebody, and since that meeting I find that he has neglected his estate altogether. He mounts his horse early in the morning, and goes away, nobody knows where, and comes back late in the evening, nobody knows why. I dare say he has discovered that our island produces something else beside sugar, rats, bats, lizards, monkeys, and boa constrictors. Perhaps he has found some pretty slave girl a little too pretty. These young men from Paris are easily caught, but such things don't last. Don't be alarmed for your prospects.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I am very thankful for your kind designs for my happiness, but could I really suppose Alphonse de Nyon capable of debasing himself by such a liaison as you hint at, I would spurn his hand though it offered me the whole Isle of France.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: When you talk of spurning a hand which, by the way, has never yet been offered you, you do not seem quite aware –

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I assure you, Sir –

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Aware that I owed to this young man's father, and now owe to himself, a sum of money which I shall never be able to pay, and to raise which the sale of every atom of property I have in the world would be insufficient; and that he holds, among the rest of his father's papers, certain bonds and mortgages from me, which give him absolute power over my estate and my person.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I remember all, Sir; but Alphonse is far too generous, too high-minded, to avail himself of such power.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p:
Don't suppose I doubt his good intentions; but he is young, confiding, thoughtless, and may be extravagant—such a creditor becomes, spite of himself, more cruel than the very
usurer. I would not buy my own safety at the price of your happiness, but if Alphonse de Nyon should become your husband –

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: We shall see, papa; we shall see. Only you must own, you yourself have been trying to damage any little regard I might fancy I felt for him, by telling me your wicked suspicions. But here he is, to confute them all.

div.stage: Enter Alphonse,

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Ah! young truant! (Alphonse raises his hat and greets them cordially.) Did the cannon disturb you in casting up your account books ? or in purifying your tubs of molasses ? Your industry does you so much credit, that your friends must forgive you for neglecting them.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Don't say neglecting them, my dear sir, though I own I have been remiss. Still (politely to Virginie), the loss to myself has been so great, that I –

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Come, come, no compliments; the Jacobins have denounced them in Paris itself. But I fear you are but half a revolutionist, citizen soldier.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: But half, indeed, sir; and less than half, if to be more implies Jacobinism.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Ha, you are a philanthropist, and repudiate the guillotine; thinking, like an excellent Christian and soldier, that throats should be cut only with the sword. Had you remained in France –

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Who could remain in France, my dear Damiron? A human shambles, with fiends for the butchers ? I am no bigot. Born an aristocrat, I saw but too clearly the crimes of my order. I saw that we were dancing on the volcano. I saw millions ground down to hopeless misery that a few might madden through fevered revels, almost less to be envied than the squalid despair which they mocked. Then the volcano awoke, and hideous was the retribution. At first, it was justice— wild justice; but the doom of still wilder guilt. For myself, though my order was no more, my title abolished, I could not condemn the struggles of a nation, which, shattering her dungeons, and shivering her chains, bade man, the image of his Maker, stand erect in the presence of his brother clay. But when a people, frantic in its new found liberty, turned to vengeance—not upon its oppressors, who had fled from the storm—but upon the guiltless and the helpless, when I saw the grey hairs of age, the golden curls of the child, and the bright tresses of woman, mangled day after day by the accursed axes of a rabble, my very heart sickened, Damiron, and I left my country for ever. But I am a Frenchman still, and my arm and my sword are France's to the last.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: You intend, I suppose, to join your regiment, which is now arriving?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I am here to meet it; and as we shall, in all probability, be stationed here for some time, I shall hope for the happiness of cultivating an acquaintance to which I owe so many advantages.

div.stage: [They exchange bows.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: But the superintendence of your estate will doubtless continue to occupy you. Had your father expected that you would be so (ironically) prudent and careful, he would hardly have imposed so many restrictions upon the disposal of your property.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: To what restrictions do you refer ?

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Oh, you must study his will. For example, fearing you might bring idle notions of the rights of man—is not that the phrase ?—from France with you, he wisely provided against your emancipating your slaves.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: But is there no such power reserved to me?

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: None. You are absolutely precluded from setting any of them free. I suppose your excellent father feared that, with your fashionable, new-fangled nations of liberty, you could be insensible of the value of such property. But you are so completely a man of business that you may safely be trusted.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I regret that hitherto my exertions have not been very assiduous.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Don't be modest, fame does you more justice.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Hush, papa ! (to him.)

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Nonsense. Yes, my good young friend, we are rejoiced to hear such good accounts of you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Aha!

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: That you devote hour after hour every day, to a pursuit which –

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Which enraptures me!

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: To cares which most young men would think wearisome.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I rather doubt that. What does he mean ?

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: But you will be richly rewarded for so much attention.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I am richly rewarded, and I hope to be rewarded still more highly.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Though it is not often that a military man has such a taste.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: The army is sadly belied then.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: I trust you do not meet with many difficulties.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Yes, with several.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Ah! patience will overcome them, if you go on with your present energy.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I cannot discover his drift.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p:
Papa is jesting with you, Lieutenant de Nyon; before you arrived, he had been complaining bitterly that you
neglected your fine property, and spent your time in—in riding about the island.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I have been observed, then, it appears. (Aloud) Indeed, Mademoiselle Damiron, I own—

div.stage: Enter Latour, observing them.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Yes, that's it; a man who owns the estate you do, ought to look after it. If you were a poor man, or a man who had no property to lose; such a man as –

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: (advancing between Damiron and Alphonse) As Antony Latour, for example, here present. Confess, M. Damiron, that I was the unhappy Helot you were about to expose, for the instruction of this young Spartan.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Well, you are not a model, it must be admitted, M. Antony.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Except in personal appearance, you were going to add. I salute you, Mdlle Damiron (she bows haughtily), and you, also, Lieutenant. The Isle of France ought to pension me handsomely, for my services in playing the part of an awful warning to her inhabitants.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: The warning will be lost upon me, I fear, until I am made aware of your offence, and its punishment.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Sir, I am in debt.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Is that all ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: All, sir! No, sir, it is not all. I am haunted.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Haunted!

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Yes, sir, and by a ghost which obstinately declines to be laid in the Red Sea.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Because, being a Jew, he is not on speaking terms with the ghosts of the Egyptians. Here he is.Enter Bokes.Don't be frightened, Bokes, I'm not dead.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: I wish you were dead, I wish the whole world was dead. I wish I was dead myself. I do. I wish I may die if I don't.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Bokes, you are ungrateful to Providence, which forwarded you to this delightful island, and then gave you such a debtor as myself.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Damn the island, and all the people upon it. In course I don't mean you, M. Damiron, because you're an honourable man, and pays your way; but –

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: But you mean me, because I owe you four thousand francs or so.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Which, it's my opinion, I shall never see a stiver of in this here world.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Well, do you know, it's rather my opinion too ? But that ought not to make you forget the delicacies of life.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p:
If you'd have forgot the delicacies of life, you
wouldn't have wanted my money. It's all gone in wines, and liqueurs, and ices, I believe.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Then you believe a great lie, for at least half of it is gone in gambling.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: There now ! he owns it, he says it, he avouches it, and there's never a blush on that copper-coloured Creole skin of his.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.stage: (suddenly changing his careless, arrogant manner, for extreme passion)
sp.p: Hark you, sir, as you value your own skin. (In this speech, the bitterness of the Creole is made apparent.) You have contrived to sneak into an island, where it is the custom of certain persons (he looks round) to treat the Creole as if his blood were not far better than their own. But no taunt (sinking his voice) from a Jew, if he prizes anything except his gold—such a trifle as his neck, for example. But (recovering his ease) I ought to apologise for allowing him to irritate me (he bows slightly) into passion.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Well, I think you ought. I didn't mean to hurt your feelings ; but four thousand francs is a deal of money to lose. [Alphonse and Virginie converse apart.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Papa, Lieutenant de Nyon thinks that, as he has been established in the island some time, it would be hospitable if he were to give a ball to the officers of his regiment on their arrival.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: It'll cost a deal of money. [They laugh.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: With all my heart. But, as his own house is hardly adapted for such a thing, had he not better take ours ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: You are most kind. Let us talk about it.

div.stage: [Damiron, Alphonse, and Virginie converse.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Now, that was a stupid offer for a man of sense to make. Why couldn't he let the young fellow have his own plates and glasses broke, eh, Mr. Latour ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Everybody has not your mixture of courtesy, liberality, and prudence, Mr. Bokes.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Now, that's said very prettily; and I take it kind in you, Mr. Latour, after what's passed—I do.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: With all his avarice and cunning, the little animal's easily softened by a few smooth words. If I didn't hate him as a creditor, I should call him kind-hearted. (Aloud) The fact is, my friend, you and I are a good deal in the same boat. People here despise me as a Creole, and you as a Jew.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Despise me! I'll take any wager, now, that I could buy up the estates of both them men as stands bowing and talking there, about dancing and nonsense. Come !

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: In buying one you buy the other, as I happen to know, and as they shall find I do. (To him) But you have not much money in the island, I think.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p:
Do you ? I don't know what you call much, but
I've got half a million of francs, and more to that, in the island, if you call that much.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Half a million of francs! (Aside) And no way I can get at it (smiling). It seems horrible. I must devise something.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Then that is settled. The ball to take place to-night.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: May I venture to hope for the honour of Mdlle. Damiron's hand early in the evening ?

div.stage: [She looks at her father.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: We will talk about that when the invitations are issued. (Aside to Alphonse) We don't want him at all.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.stage: (Biting his lip, but bowing, and then coming down)
sp.p: Insult again ! But the time will come.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: But unless there is any other objection than his birth –

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: We think that enough here. But as you please.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Then I should wish to show him some courtesy. Monsieur Latour, you have only anticipated me—I was about to ask you to favour us with your presence.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I thank you sincerely, sir. (Aside) If I find he intends courtesy, I may not forget it.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Nobody asks me ; but I suppose I may come.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Certainly; unless Monsieur Latour objects.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Oh! he won't object. He likes me. We love one another like brothers .

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Cain and Abel, for choice.

div.stage: [Cannon heard again.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: The troops have arrived ! Let us go down and see them disembark.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I will remain. For the moment, adieu !

div.stage: [Exeunt Damiron and Virginie.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Unless you are otherwise occupied, I should be glad of a word with you, Monsieur de Nyon.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: I'll bet he's going to try to borrow money of him, and t'other's just the sort of fellow to lend it. If I don't go, he'll appeal to me for a character, and then I shall be let in. ( Going.)

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Bokes –

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: No; I dare say you're solvent and responsible, and strictly honourable, and your name's as good as the Bank of France; but I haven't time to stop and tell Mr. De Nyon so just now.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: You mistake.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Do I ? So much the better for him—and I'll go, before the mistake's made into the true story. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I shall venture to speak to you, Monsieur de Nyon, with some freedom; although what you have heard here is not likely to increase your wish for my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: If you allude to pecuniary matters, remember that I have lived among the luxurious prodigality of Paris. If—but I hope you do not—you refer to any class prejudices, pray remember, also, that in the army of the Republic we do not ask by what right a man bears arms, but how he bears them.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: The answer I expected. (With his former tone of ease.) You appear to be on the most intimate terms with this worthy Monsieur Damiron, Lieutenant ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Naturally, is it not so ? He was my father's friend.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: He was ; and you are doubtless aware that everything Damiron has in the world is your own.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Mine !

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: At least, you have so much that he is very anxious you should have a little more. When you have time to examine your box of deeds, you will find an excellent reason why Damiron should be attentive to you; and a still better— why his daughter should do her best to secure your affections.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: My affections! Mdlle. Damiron!

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Unless you are blinded by some other light, (significantly) one would say that you have less penetration than is usual to men of your age.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: They are both very obliging; but I have not noticed any especial assiduity.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Notice it now. I will tell you one thing. Their observation of yourself and your movement is far more vigilant.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Ha! is it so? And what do you suppose is the result ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: What should it be? Your daily visit, and protracted stay at a cottage, not upon your own estate, have not escaped the knowledge of so careless a person as myself, who nave no concern in your affairs. Is it likely that interested parties are worse informed?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: And by what right has any one played spy upon me ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: In Damiron's case, the right of self-preservation.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I do not comprehend.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Not? May I speak out?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I entreat it.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Why, Damiron, of course, discovered that there was a lady in the case. His next step, and his comfort, was to discover that marriage between that lady and you was out of the question.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Yes. Knowing what you do know, you are, I suppose, aware that she is young, beautiful, and accomplished. I have no reason for concealing from you that I love her with an ardour –

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: You astonish me!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: What ?—is there anything astonishing in a man's loving such a person as I have described.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: No; but are you ignorant, then. (Aside) If she should have kept him in the dark! (Aloud) How, may I ask, were you introduced to this lady ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: By one of those simple accidents, almost too commonplace to tell. I was riding one morning on the verge of my own estate, when, seeing a smooth piece of turf extending down a forest avenue, I thoughtlessly gave my horse spur and rein, and dashed down the path at full speed. Halfway in the race, a white object, hitherto unseen, rose, and startled him. He swerved violently, and I, who was riding carelessly, was flung upon the turf, slightly stunned by the fall, but not hurt. When I recovered, I found the white object was the dress of a young lady, who was sedulously sprinkling me with water— and there is the whole story.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Then this young lady, at whose feet you threw yourself so early in your acquaintance, is the person you visit so constantly ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: May I ask her name ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: There is no reason for concealment. Her name is Louise Fauriel.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: She has kept to the truth, so far.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Do you know the name, or the owner ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Both. But where does she reside ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: In a cottage not far from the scene of my accident. I insisted on attending her home — she refused—I pressed it, and succeeded. All that remains to be told is, that I love her to madness.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: And intend to prove your madness by marriage?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: This is very strange! (Aloud) Pray did you, like a preux chevalier, disclose your name, estate, and prospects, or –

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: No, I am ashamed to say that I dared to doubt her— that I was eager to be loved for myself alone—and that I described myself as a young and fortuneless traveller, named Henri Briseux. She loves me; of that I have been assured by her own sweet lips. But even while making that avowal, she declared, with tears, that our union was impossible.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: That is true !

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: She has hinted that a dreadful barrier exists between us, which she dares not indicate more clearly; and, but that in the earnestness of my love I have vowed that all barriers shall be overcome, I should despair of my heart's destiny.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: You need not. I will ensure you against failure. Nay, your success shall be immediate.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: You doubt me—not unreasonably.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Nay, not you ; but the promise is so large.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: If the performance fall short of it, stamp me as a braggart—join in the popular scorn of the Creole. This hour, before your soldiers are released from duty, you will hear of me. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: If it should be so. A strange promise; but he spoke with apparent sincerity. Dearest Louise, to love her, to be loved by her, were ecstacy enough for a life ; yet it will be no mean joy when, with her white hand upon my heart, I tell her to whom she has yielded her own—when I hail her as mistress of yonder noble estate, the noblest in the island, yet not too rich an offering to lay at her feet. (Distant march.) Ah ! (He goes to the terrace). The troops are forming on the beach. I will join my old companions there.

div.stage: [As the music grows louder, Alphonse exit, and scene closes.

div.head: Scene II.—Interior of a cottage.
div.stage: Enter Louise—she has been weeping. She buries her face in her hands, and sobs bitterly.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: No more—no more—to see him no more—slight words—slight words—but an agony—a despair. To see him no more—to listen no more for the light step that came as a signal to the pulse to dance in joy—to meet no more the bright and ardent glance that sparkled with the delight it was bringing—to hear no more the gentle words that I loved so, that I loved for the love they spoke, and for the tones of music in which they fell—no more—oh ! Heaven, have mercy on me! (Weeps passionately.) But the doom is spoken—the dreadful barrier looms hideously upon me. I dared not disclose it to him—I could not bear that he should learn it from my lips— that I should see him shudder—it might be, repulse me from his arms.—No! that he could never do—not that, not that! But to have told him—to have seen him stricken into mourning silence, and turning hopelessly away, while I—I—-with a brain of fire, and lips of ashes, should have avowed my shame—(wildly) it could not be—the sacrifice could not be demanded from a wretched girl. (Moaningly) No more—no more.

div.stage: Enter Latour (unobserved by her.)

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Tears! As I expected. Let me try my powers of drying them. Mdlle. Fauriel (she raises her head, but gazes on him without speaking) I have the honour of bringing a message to you.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: To me ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: A message which it will probably give you pleasure to hear.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: Pleasure to me ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I trust so (Louise relapses into indifference) when I mention the name of Monsieur Henri Briseux.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: Of him! No.—In mercy's name, do not speak of him. Leave me, Monsieur Latour, leave me to my misery.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: On the contrary, I would separate you from it.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: You have seen him, Monsieur Latour. You have told him all. Is it not so ? Do not deceive one who has no means of redress or revenge, let who will injure her.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I have told him nothing.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: Nothing ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: On my honour—you, at least, will not sneer at the honour of a Creole. But we have no time for talk. Will you accompany me to the town ? I am charged to introduce you to a friend.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: I have no friends.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: More than you know of. But this is a friend of my own—M. de Nyon.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: M. de Nyon—the name is familiar.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: It ought to be.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: The new owner ?—the—(shuddering)

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: The young proprietor of the splendid estate of L'Etoile. (significantly)

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: Must I go ? (helplessly) Must I go, M. Latour ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Allow me to be your escort.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: Cannot—will not—another day—to-morrow-I am very sad—very ill –

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: You will regret postponement.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: I will go.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: In a few moments I –

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I will wait you in the garden.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: I was wrong, I was wrong to say there was no comfort in the intensity of my grief—this meeting —this humiliation—dreaded so long, seem trifles now. Wretched—most wretched ! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: This meeting will be strange. Two persons at more singular cross purposes have hardly met. But whether one or both will thank me for the introduction remains to be seen. The proud blood of the Frenchman, and the fiery current which animates our pretty friend here, may both blaze out with a fury which will make the experiment hazardous. But we shall see—we shall see. If matters go as I have planned, there will fell to my share two very delightful things—money and revenge! [Exit.

div.head: Scene III.— (Same as first.)
div.stage:
Music heard, gradually nearer. Then a rush upon the stage by spectators of the
paraded troops—native, in their picturesque dresses—and group right and left. Then, more leisurely, the respectable inhabitants, with slates attending upon them. When the stage is nearly filled, enter, as at the head of soldiers, Hyacinth St. Emilion, with his sword drawn. He makes signals, and the troops enter, and are drawn up at the back— stand at ease. Amid the bustle, Damiron and Virginie enter, and take their places. Then Alphonse enters, and Hyacinthe rushes down to salute him.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Welcome to the Isle of France !

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: Thank you, my friend—thank you! Your Isle of France is charming; but, by all the Saints we have blotted out of the calendar, after such a voyage as we have had, I don't think we should have complained if we had landed, by mistake, at the Isle of Devils.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: We have been impatient for your arrival.

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: The impatience was mutual, I can tell you. I hate the sea, and ships, and everything about them! It's a fine thing to be able to lift up your foot with a certainty of finding a place to put it down upon There—there—once more I tread as firmly as if I were in the Place de Carousel.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: And what news from France ?

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: Oh! I don't know. Vulgar, vulgar—all vulgar— cutting off heads, and abolishing Sundays, and I don't know what. Ask the other fellows—I've no time to waste on such things. What sort of women have you here ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Angels!

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: Cieux ! what a change from those of Paris ! But, do you know, I think I like the Paris breed best—I've rather a prejudice against angels.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: We shall please you. Let me introduce you to some of my oldest friends here.

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: Old angels ? (laughing.)

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: No—no. Come here. (Takes him up to Damiron and Virginie, and introduces him.) The most thoughtless and the least heartless of my comrades.

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: Ah! that is unfair. But to the second part of the charge I must plead guilty. Since my introduction to Mdlle. Damiron, I am utterly heartless. (Virginie smiles and bows: the others laugh.) If she is one of the angels, I retract what I said against them. But I suppose the young lady is your conquest ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Not at all. Take your chance.

div.stage: [They go up closer, and talk to Virginie.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: But I miss somebody. Where is that dashing little lady with the saucy swagger, and the merry laugh who has amused us so much ?

div.stage: [Bellona's voice heard singing, "Cadet Rouselle e trois maisons," &c.
Enter Bellona, dressed as a Vivandiere, very smart and military.

sp.speaker: Bellona.
sp.p: Here she is, most respectable civilian, and delighted to contribute to the happiness of yourself or any other friend, (gravely) supposing him to be a friend of France. Lieutenant Alphonse, I am charmed to see you again. I have kept the manners and morals of our regiment in tolerable order, but I wanted you sadly; (confidentially) the notions of the younger men are not quite what they ought to be, you see, upon several subjects. Lieutenant Hyacinthe!

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: Bellona !

sp.speaker: Bellona.
sp.p: Approach me, if you please.

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: She is despotic, you observe.

div.stage: [Comes up to Bellona.

sp.speaker: Bellona.
sp.p: What are your intentions in regard to that young person you are talking to ?

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: Strictly honourable. She's rich.

sp.speaker: Bellona.
sp.p: You have leave. (Hyacinthe laughs and returns to Virginie. Bellona suddenly returns to her usual vivacity.) So, this is the Isle of France. I respect it for its very name. I say, Alphonse, we have had such a race for our lives.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: Bellona.
sp.p: I, and the regiment, and the ship—in fact, all of us.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Who has been chasing you?

sp.speaker: Bellona.
sp.p: Our natural enemies, of course.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: The English ?

sp.speaker: Bellona.
sp.p: Oh, don't mention them! How I do hate them!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I did not hear of this.

sp.speaker: Bellona.
sp.p: Well, it's not pleasant to talk about, but you ought to be au fait at the history of the regiment. You see, one afternoon during the voyage, I was lying in a hammock they had hung for me on deck, that I might keep my eye upon the soldiers. I was mending my model of the guillotine here (shows a silver ornament)—what a fine thing the guillotine is!—and I was nursing a poor dear little baby that was born on board, when I saw the English flag in the distance.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: That's where I like to see it—in the extreme distance.

sp.speaker: Bellona.
sp.p: I shouted at the captain—the captain shouted at the first lieutenant—the first lieutenant shouted at the second lieutenant—he shouted at the men—the men shouted at one another—and, in short, everybody shouted at everybody.

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: It's a way they have in our navy. I think it's vulgar, but I suppose it's useful.

sp.speaker: Bellona.
sp.p:
You be quiet—you shouted as much as anybody. Well, out came the telescopes, and we soon made out that our
enemy was a celebrated English cruiser. So we crowded all sail, and bore away as fast as we could.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Why the vessel there carries nearly twice as many guns as any of the English cruisers.

sp.speaker: Bellona.
sp.p: That was just it. We agreed that it would be treason to France to risk the loss of all our guns against such a miserable handful. So away we went. But the cruiser was alive, and in a few minutes we found that she, too, was crowding all sail to chase us. Away we flew, tearing through the blue water like a frightened sea monster, and flinging the spray aside till it fell like the roar of a cataract. But after us came the cruiser, swift, steady, and spiteful as a hawk, and it was easy to see that she was rapidly gaining upon us. On we raced, and raced. Presently came a flash, and a puff of white smoke, and then the roar of a gun, and a cannon ball went splashing along the water. " The next won't miss," said the Captain, and sure enough he was right. Another flash, and puff, and roar, and down came our maintop gallant mast upon deck, as if it had fallen from the clouds. " Oh ! my blessed babby," said I, " you'll be christened at Portsmouth and educated on beer."

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: However, you escaped.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes; but however we escaped I don't know, for the cruiser kept on throwing us those infernal bon bons, until the light shone through our sails in a most remarkable manner, while she gained upon us so terribly that I could see clusters of half-naked brawny-looking men, with cutlasses in their hands, clinging to the shrouds and chains, and obviously intending to honour us with their particularly unwelcome presence on deck. So I ran down stairs, or what d'ye call it, put baby to bed, and got a blunderbuss.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: You, a blunderbuss !

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes; I wasn't going to Portsmouth, without fighting for it, I can tell you. While I was tucking up baby, and kissing it, and tying its night gown for the last time, as I thought, all of a sudden darkness came on—a sea fog swallowed us all up—and when it cleared away there was no cruiser to be seen, and so here we are. (Sings, and takes a step or two to the music, "Cadet Rouselle a trois enfans, &c."

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: Who is this ? Another angel of the island ?

div.stage: Enter Bokes, hastily.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: I won't stay in this island. The island's a disgrace to the ocean, and that's all about it. I wish it was sunk for twenty, or five-and-twenty minutes, under the water.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: That's treason to France, you good-for-nothing little creature! Who are you, and what's the matter with you ?

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: And who are you as asks, and why ain't your petticoats longer ?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What's that to you ? What harm has the island done you, and what harm have my petticoats done you ?

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Curse the island.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Energetic, but not explicit.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: I have been half killed.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Who has been fool enough to do things by halves ?

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: A woman.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: It's not the general fault of our sex. What woman ?

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: A Malagash, they call her, whatever that means.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: I advise you, my friend, to leave the Malagash women alone.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: And why the deuce couldn't you tell me so before, instead of after ?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What was your offence.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Nothing. I lost my way.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ah! that's often an excuse for a gentleman's being found where he has no business.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: So, seeing a woman sitting on a bit of wood, I bawled to her, to know where I was. She took no notice, so I pulled her dress—I call it dress, but it was nothing but an old sheet. The moment I touched her, up she flew—out came a knife, and if I hadn't run harder than I ever ran in all my life, I should have forgotten all my complaints in about five minutes. She followed me a long way, and I knew she meant to murder me.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: She will. You have inflicted what is the deadliest insult in the eyes of one of these Malagash women—you have touched her dress. Make your mind easy—there is no doubt on the matter—she'll kill you.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: She won't, for I'll leave the island, and throw myself into the hands of the English. One good thing about them English is, that though they bully you themselves, they won't let anybody else do it.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: I may as well inform you, that if you are detected in the slightest communication with an English vessel, the governor will hang you.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: What! without a trial ?

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: No; there'll be a trial whether the rope is strong enough.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Then what am I to do ? I musn't be killed. I'm a rich man, and I can't afford to die.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes, yes, be extravagant for once.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: You mind your own business.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Listen to me, you dissatisfied wretch ! The people here can't protect you, and the English shan't. I will.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I. In the name of France, I take you into alliance I annex you.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Thank you. I accept your offer.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Henceforth, then, you are under the flag of France; and whoever kills you will incur her displeasure.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: And mine, most heartily. What am I to do ?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Keep close to me, and obey orders.

div.stage: Enter Latour.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Still here. I can hardly prevail on her to remain with me. I must hasten the introduction. Lieutenant de Nyon!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Ha! returned! (Comes down to him: the others draw back, speaking in groups.) You have seen her ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: And where is she ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Close at hand.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Let me hurry to her –

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: That were to break her commands. I will conduct her to you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Dear Louise! Then be speedy, my friend.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: The crisis of the experiment. It is like waiting the throw of the dice, after you have called. Now !

div.stage: [Exit.

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: You seem excited.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: My dear Hyacinthe, I am expecting the presence of one whom I love better than life itself.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: (to Hyacinthe) What is disturbing your friend ?

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: Nothing. He is merely expecting a lady to whom he tells me he is deeply attached.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Attached ! (In a low voice) Papa –

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Silence, my love! I am attending.[Enter Latour with Louise. Louise shrinks tremblingly back, but Damiron and Virginie see her.Ha! a load is off my mind. No fear, then !

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Yet, how disgraceful, this public recognition !

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Hush!

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: Which—which is my—my –

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: De Nyon!

div.stage: [Alphonse advances. As he does so Louise is brought forward a few steps before she looks in his face: then, suddenly recognising him, she gazes, astounded.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Louise!

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: That, Monsieur de Nyon!

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: One moment. Everything in form. Mdlle. Louise Fauriel, I have the honour of pointing out to you your Master. Monsieur Alphonse de Nyon, permit me to present you with your Slave.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Slave! Are you mad?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Your slave, Monsieur de Nyon. Accident prevented her meeting you on your arrival. You know how, and why—the secret has since been kept.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: A slave!

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: That Monsieur de Nyon! (faintly). Henri (with piteous reproach), should you have done this ?

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: The poor girl is certainly your property, De Nyon. The proofs are among your papers.

div.stage: [Bellona has come down, and looks with interest at each, and with compassion at Louise.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: A slave! Yet—yet—I—Louise!

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.stage: (tremulous, but hoping that he is going to embrace her, half advances; but he draws himself up haughtily. She stops, and presses her hand suddenly upon her brow.)
sp.p: I had forgotten—The Slave's Place Is At Her Master's Feet!

div.stage: [With an hysteric cry, she falls at his feet. Bellona rushes forward to raise her as the Drop descends.
Scene I.—A handsome apartment in the house of Alphonse De Nyon. Table with fruits, flowers, and cut glasses. He is seated with wine near him.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Why, why did she deceive me ? Why leave me to frame, in the buoyant subtlety of love, a thousand imaginary obstacles to our union, obstacles over each of which, in its turn, I could meditate and triumph, while the dreadful truth remained to annihilate at a blow all strength, all hope. A slave! My slave! I have here (takes up papers) the accursed proof which separates us for ever, while declaring her irrevocably mine. The slave whose beauty, whose grace, whose intellect—charms that might intoxicate the very soul of the prostrate lover, exulting in the thought that they were for him alone—the slave, whom the law pronounces incapable of uttering the marriage vow, the slave is mine ! And such is the end of my day dream.

div.stage: Enter Bellona.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How melancholy he looks ! It does him credit (tries to sing, but her voice changes to a cry), "Cadet Rouselle est bon enfant," &c. No, it's no use. Lieutenant!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: You here!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
Why, where would you have me be ? Who was there
to take care of that poor girl but me, when all the rest of you stood up as coldly as if the beautiful creature lying on the ground wasn't made of flesh and blood, and much better flesh and blood than most of those who were too proud to help her. Who was there to bring her here ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Here!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And where else ? Whose roof has a right to shelter her, but your own ? For that matter, she won't want shelter long, I think, if her poor heart is to go on beating at the rate it has kept for the last hour, to say nothing of her eyes, which are trying to drown themselves (half crying all this time).

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: And my name, does she mention that ? But don't tell me. What is the knowledge to me ?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I tell you what, Lieutenant; my opinion is, that everybody is behaving very ill to this girl; and, and (struggling to regain her usual off-hand manner) I won't allow it—at least, for the honour of the regiment, I won't allow you to have any share in the matter.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Nobody has so much cause to complain as myself.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Of course, that is the belief of every man who misconducts himself. Oh, it's no use your looking angrily at me. You forget that I once looked Robespierre himself full in his ugly face, and I'm alive to tell it.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I cannot jest with you, Bellona.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I shouldn't advise it, Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: You do not understand the affair.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Do I not ? I own it's difficult to understand a story that a poor creature tells you in a passion of sobs, but one woman has great helps in trying to comprehend another.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Louise, then, has confided in you ?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: That's right, call her Louise, and I shall have hopes for you and for her. Yes, she has told me everything.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: How she deceived me, concealing the fact that she was my slave?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How you deceived her, concealing the fact that you were her master.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: On my part, the concealment was an instinct of love.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And on her's, the instinct of nature, grateful for that love. Come, De Nyon, do justice to her character and your own. You loved; but in the very outset you dared to doubt, and to satisfy that unworthy distrust you forged a falsehood. Had you spoken the truth, all your suffering, and her's, would have been saved.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: You plead earnestly for her, but not half so earnestly as her advocate here (touches his heart).

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Trust to both counsellors then, and all may be well. [Servant announces " Monsieur Latour." And (in a lower voice) do not trust to that counsellor, or nothing will be well.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: You are deceived ; his intentions are good.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I don't know ; but good intentions are the pavement of a certain place, and (aside) I shouldn't care if Monsieur Latour went to survey his own paving. I should like to know what he is come about; and what's more I will know. (Aloud) Adieu, for the present, Lieutenant.

div.stage: [Sings as she goes out, " Cadet Rouselle a trois belles sœurs," &c.
Enter Latour.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I do not know whether I am welcome.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Be seated. I have not much cordiality to spare for anybody, as you will conjecture.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Can I serve you further in the affair in which you have done me the honour to consult me ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: What possible service can you, or any other mortal, render me in—in—such a matter ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: You surprise me! I must have misunderstood the words you used this morning.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: To what do you refer ? Circumstances may have changed with me, but I have nothing to retract—nothing to forget.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Then, forgive me, if I understood you to say you loved this girl.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Loved ! At least there is no change there.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: But this morning your thoughts went even beyond love; or, as some would say, not so far; you spoke of marriage.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Assuredly! I looked forward to an union with Mdlle. Fauriel as the one object for which life was dear.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: That idea you have given to the winds ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Such a question from you ! Do you ask me if I have resigned the idea of marrying Louise Fauriel ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: That is my inquiry.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: The—the—slave ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Is her state of slavery the obstacle, Monsieur de Nyon –

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Is it not an insurmountable one ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I seldom believe in insurmountable obstacles. Not in this, at all events. For argument's sake, suppose it surmounted—would the proud blood of France forget the past, forgive the absence of pedigree, and rest satisfied with youth, beauty, and love ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p:
Gladly! oh, most gladly! To call Louise my wife,
I would defy the prejudices of a world. But why present an impossibility ? Louise Fauriel is a slave.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: You are her master—her sole irresponsible owner. Why not enfranchise her ? An oath, and a stroke of the pen will do it. Louise is free, and then if you can induce her to assume another chain –

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Unhappily, by the will of my father, I am precluded from enfranchising a slave for five years to come. I am powerless.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I am perfectly aware of the fact—all goes well! (To him) That indeed destroys hope. (Affects to consider) Yet—yet—I—a suggestion crosses my brain—I hardly know whether –

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Speak!

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Can you trust me, De Nyon ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I am prepared to execute anything you can propose, provided it be consistent with honour.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Even the Creole (bitterly) would propose nothing dishonourable, Monsieur de Nyon.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Speak, I beg of you.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Now my project trembles in the balance. One grain of enthusiasm, or one grain of suspicion will turn either scale. (To him) You would enfranchise Louise Fauriel, Monsieur de Nyon, but your father's will prevents you. I once had some slaves, but, unfortunately, having no father's will to show, they became the property of the creditors to whom I disposed of them.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: And why tell me this ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: To show you that I have absolute power over any slave I may possess. Suppose, for a moment—and do not start at the idea—that Louise were mine.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Your's?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I repeat it—you are surely not boy enough to be terrified by words ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Proceed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Suppose she were mine—absolutely, unconditionally —so far as documents go—otherwise, my power would be insufficient. Any friend who should then say to me "Antony Latour, will you possess Louise Fauriel as a slave, or enfranchise her, and possess ten thousand francs," would speedily be called upon to disburse.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I understand you now, Latour. But how could Louise become yours.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: As her mother became your father's—by purchase.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: And you would have me sell Louise to you – sell to you the object of my heart's passion—the being whom the treasure of a world were too poor to buy ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p:
Stay, Sir. No unnecessary display of eloquence. I have no more to say. Had you condescended to
hear me, you would, perhaps, have replied differently. I spoke, as I foolisly supposed, for your benefit. Good morning, M. de Nyon.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Stay, Latour, stay ! You have never loved, Latour, or you would not weigh so scrupulously a lover's words. But you spoke of a purchase, of a sum of money, and of Louise in a breath.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: My scale descends. (Aloud) No, M. de Nyon, I did not speak of a sum of money in reference to our present subject. I said that any friend might so command the freedom of a slave.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: The transfer to you——

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Though apparently bone fide, would, of course, be nominal. In an hour Mdlle. Fauriel would be as much her own mistress as Mdlle. Damiron.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Damiron! Ah! (aloud) I thank you sincerely for the proposal, Latour. Have you any objection to my consulting M. Damiron upon it ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I ? None ! What is it to me ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I would simply ask Damiron's opinion of the plan.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: But if you tell him our object he will, of course, vehemently oppose it.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: He will oppose it, from regard to my father.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: He will oppose it from regard to his daughter. I observed his pleased look this morning when he found that her rival was only a slave. Tell him one half of the project only —say nothing about your matrimonial intentions—or rather, for here he comes, let me be spokesman—you will correct me if I make an error.

div.stage: Enter Damiron. At the same time Bellona steals in behind them, and hides herself behind some orange plants.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Our arrangements for the ball are very forward, De Nyon ; we don't take long to fit up rooms here, so I told Virginie I would come round for any final directions you might wish to give.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Your visit is well timed, Damiron; for I am about to ask your advice.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: As much of it as you think worth having, my dear boy!

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: The point is this, Monsieur Damiron; and nobody can advise Monsieur de Nyon better than yourself.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: I am all attention.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So am I.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Of course the unhappy scene of to-day has dwelt upon our friend's mind.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: And upon mine; and I may add, upon poor Virginie's too. The child is quite miserable about it.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p:
That's false—the old humbug! (To him
Following the natural bent of his disposition, Monsieur de Nyon would have at once enfranchised the girl Louise, given her the means of subsistence, and sent her out of the island.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh ! what a ! Never mind.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: I wish he could. (To them) Our friend's humanity is great, and renders him liable to be led into traps.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Not such traps as you can bait. (Aloud) But, as you, sir, are aware, his father's will makes that impossible. So he has resolved—subject to your advice always —on selling the girl to me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I shall rush in directly, and scatter them all right and left!

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Latour must be buying her wonderfully cheap. He hasn't a sou in the world. But I don't care: De Nyon can afford to lose the price, and she'll be out of the way. (To him) I think, Latour, that De Nyon evinces great good sense, and I quite approve of the plan.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The old wretch! the cold-blooded old wretch ! But not half so bad as the young ones.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: How hard it is to hear the affair discussed with such brutal coldness ! Yet I must bear it.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Forgive me. Supposing that hereafter our friend's wish of liberating and providing for the girl should be carried out, there will be no difficulty, I imagine ?

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: None in the world —none. The slave is yours.

div.stage: [Alphonse shudders.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: You hear Monsieur Damiron's opinion, Lieutenant de Nyon?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Yes. Nothing can be more satisfactory.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: They will murder the girl among 'em; but I'll save her yet! [Rushes out.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: If you wish to effect this at once—and the sooner the better— the proper officer is now in attendance.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Instantly! (Aside) I seem to revolt at the means; and yet there are no others. Damiron's advice, too—it shall be done. She shall be free in an hour.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: I will go down and prepare the necessary contract. Follow me as soon as you please. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: How eager the old fox is to get Louise out of the way! How little he thinks of what I am preparing for him, and his disinterested darling of a daughter ! (Aloud) Are you ready, De Nyon?

div.stage: [Noise without. Louise's voice is heard.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: Where—where? Let me see him—let me see him !

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Ha! she will spoil all. (Aloud) Stay, De Nyon; I hear Mdlle. Fauriel's voice. You had better come at once.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Nay ; I will speak to her.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Peste ! Very well. But one word. (Energetically) The whole transaction will be vitiated and legally void if she knows its object. You must not tell her. Rely on this, as law.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Is it so ? Then I will be silent. It is only an hour.

div.stage: Enter Louise wildly, followed by Bellona. The moment she sees Alphonse she runs to him, and clasps his arm. Latour draws back to watch. Bellona on the other side of Alphonse.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: What! Why is this, Louise?

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: Oh ! forgive me. What have I done ! what have I done ! I did not mean it to offend you, whatever it was. But forgive me, Henri ! Do not —do not, in mercy, send me away !

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: You are talking wildly, Louise.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: I have called you Henri. I had no right to call you so. The word came unbidden. It was the name by which you taught me to love you. But I was wrong. I will not call you so again. But speak to me—speak to me, Monsieur—Monsieur de Nyon. Tell me that you will not let me be sold!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: (to Latour) She has heard it!

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Perhaps not all.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: Do not drive me from your doors. Let me stay— let me but hear your footstep once in the day, once in the week, the footstep for which I used to watch and listen. M. de Nyon, will you not hear the prayer of your poor Louise ? (falls on her knees, sobbing.)

sp.speaker: Alph.
Bel.
sp.p: I, I, Lieutenant de Nyon. It was I. I have been listening, while you have plotted. I heard your project.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: If so, you must approve it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
Approve it! Alphonse de Nyon, we are not friends of yesterday. I have a right to plead with you. We have shared hardship and suffering; have we not, Alphonse ? I have attended the march of your soldiers by day and by night; we have toiled together through the storm, and over the snow, to many a glorious battle field, where all was forgotten but the banners of France. I have seen you on those long and dreary marches, riding from rank to rank, cheering the strong, helping the weak, and making all love you for the firm but gentle spirit, in which you bore on those wearied ranks to the light, where no troops were ever more forward than your own. I have seen you tending the sick, the wounded, with a
kindliness which has made the fevered eye overflow with tears of gratitude, which has raised the mangled arm to wave for you and France.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Silence—silence, for Heaven's love!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Not yet—not yet—I will plead for her, to whom you were once proud to plead. Is not the blow which has fallen upon her heavy enough ? Will you add to the agony of the bruised heart ? How has she wronged you that you would take this cruel vengeance ? Look at her, De Nyon, and say if it is upon that trembling, stricken thing, that you would heap more misery. Look at her, Alphonse, look at her! It is not much she asks. Even if I asked it, for the sake of old times, you would hardly deny it me. I ask it now, I ask it for her. Let her remain under the roof of one who taught her to love him, and who now hates her for having learned that lesson too easily. She will not annoy you— she will not reproach you—you shall not even be angered by the sight of her pale face, and wasting form, as she lingers, rather than lives, to pray for you and death.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: If I listen a moment longer, I must disclose all, come. [Rushes out, followed by Latour.

div.stage: [Louise looks piteously at Bellona, who clasps her in her arms.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My poor girl—my poor girl! But you have one friend left, who has vowed to see justice done you, and who will stay by you, while there is a pulse in her veins to beat for you ! Come, dear child, come!

div.stage: [She supports Louise from the apartment. Scene closes.

div.head: Scene II.—A Garden, belonging to the house of De Nyon.
div.stage: Enter Bokes.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Matters are looking a little better with me, I think, for here's the middle of the day, and I ain't either stabbed or hanged. Anyveres else people mightn't say that was much to brag on, but it's better than my expectations. What a confounded island it is. If I thought there was no one listening, I'd say something—and that is, that I hope, from the very bottom of my heart, the English may come and take the place. I do fervently wish they may get it. I wish I may die if I don't.Enter Bellona, wiping her eyes.Here's France, my respected ally, crying. I wonder what's happened to her now.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
She's asleep, poor child—nature could bear it no longer —no more could I. What on earth is to be done for her ? In Paris, I'd have got up a little revolution for myself, and hanged that Latour from a lamp. But here, there's a great absence of
all moral feeling. I might as well cry ca ira to a shoal of porpoises. Ah! my protégé. Come here, you Bokes.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: What's the matter—anybody picked your pocket ?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Mine ! ha, ha! They wouldn't find much, except my cigar-case, and baby's coral, and a little gunpowder, and a few songs, and a couple of horse-shoes, and some nails, and my night-cap, and a few little things of that sort.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: That's right, take care of everything. I always do.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And what on earth have you got to take care of ?

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Myself.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But setting aside rubbish ?

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Rubbish! I'm worth five hundred thousand francs.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You're rich, then ?

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Do you want a little bill done ?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I ! what do I want with money ?

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: But why do you ask if I'm rich ?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Because it occurs to me that I see a way—(aside) ha! a splendid thought!—(aloud) Yes, I see a way in which you could lay out some money to my satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Very likely; but I'm not sure that it would be to mine.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What ? Refuse a subsidy to your ally ! You'll break the entente cordiale between us.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: I haven't a guess what that is; perhaps it's the French for humbug.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Bokes, you know Monsieur Latour?

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: If I do, why remind me of my misfortunes ?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: . I think you'll have to give him some money.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: If I do, I hope I may be particularly well d——

div.stage: [She puts her hand on his mouth.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: As I should certainly compel you to break your oath, I advise you, as a moralist, not to take it. I'll tell you, Bokes. This Latour has bought something which I want.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Latour bought! That proves that you're out. How should he buy anything ?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I don't know, and, what's more, I don't care. He has bought something, and you must buy it of him for me (aside).

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: But I can get it for nothing. You are sure it is Latour's own ?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Certain; I know how he got it, and why.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Then it's mine. You see, I have been fool enough to lend this Monsieur Latour a great many francs, which I don't suppose I shall ever see any more.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I don't care!

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p:
Come, don't snap one up, like that. I tell you I took a security from him, which gives me the sole and entire right, not only over everything he had, which was nothing, but over everything he might have. Now, of course, if you
are sure this thing you speak of, and which I hope ain't a pig in a poke, is Latour's own, it's mine this very minute, or whenever I choose to claim it.[Bellona rushes about, clapping her hands, dancing, and singing very loud indeed— "Cadet Rouselle a trois enfans," &c.France is certainly cracked.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Victory ! Vive la France ! En avant.

div.stage: [Seizes him, and makes him dance round, and then off with her—she singing "Cadet Rouselle" as loud as she can.
[Exeunt.

div.head: Scene III.— (Same as first.)
div.stage: Enter Alphonse and Latour. In this scene the manner of Latour is marked by a composed decision, as of triumph and power.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: So, the formality is complete, and Mdlle. Louise Fauriel is now the absolute property of Monsieur Antony Latour.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Enfranchise her from her unhappy state, and –

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Not so fast, my good friend.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Surely, that is the next step.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: No; the next but one.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: What intervenes, in the fiend's name ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I am about to tell you, De Nyon.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Pray be explicit, and make allowances for the ardour of a lover.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Agreed, if you will do the same.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I! And who is the lover ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Myself.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: At least, I choose to play the part, and, under the circumstances, the lady can ask no more.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: This is new. Who is the lady ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I fear I must avow myself your rival.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Mine! Latour.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Unequal as is the competition, it is true.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I dare hardly trust my senses. My rival! In the affections of Louise Fauriel.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: No; I should admit no rivalry there, for the best of reasons—she is mine already. But do not be furious—I am sneaking of another person.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Of –

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Of Mdlle. Damiron.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Mdlle Damiron!

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Aided by your eloquence, I have no doubt of her father's favour.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: You know his prejudice against . Forgive me, —against your race.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: But I have great faith in your advocacy.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I confess you puzzle me. I am inclined to think that within the moment that Damiron comprehends my object, he will order me from his presence, and that within the next hour we shall cross swords.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I will ensure you against insult or injury.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Usually I can do both for myself; but in this particular case I own I shall be glad of such security. I would not willingly outrage the feelings, still less harm the person, of my father's friend.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: But he is surely too much a man of business to be offended at being treated as your father's debtor.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Ha ! What are you suggesting ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: What I am sure your good sense will approve. I avow to you plainly that I hate this Damiron. His prejudice has insulted me, and his hollow wealth has given him a title to do so. For that passable prettyness, his daughter, I am very anxious to wed her; less for her own sake than because the union would humble Damiron's pride to the very earth. You have given me a right to be confidential with you, and you see I avail myself of it.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: And is it to Alphonse de Nyon that you make a proposal that he should avail himself of the power given him by Monsieur Damiron's debts to control his disposal of his daughter's hand ? You carry a sword, sir ! [Draws

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Which I can use, when necessary. But what excuse should I offer to Mdlle. Louise for having run her lover through the body ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: You will need no such excuse. Draw, sir!

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: True-true. You remind me well that a master makes no excuses to his slave.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.stage: (about to threaten him, but suddenly drops his sword point)
sp.p: His slave!

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: His slave, sir—his slave! Louise Fauriel is mine—mine by all the force of law—mine irrevocably ! Now, Frenchman, choose your course ! You have assigned your bride to me—to me, the despised Creole. She is my slave; and if you dare to dispute my will, I may — do you hear ?—I may . Her eyes, though tearful, are still bright; her hair, though dishevelled, is still beautiful. Do you hear, Monsieur de Nyon ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Miscreant!

div.stage: [Rushes at him. Latour suddenly draws, and their swords cross.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Come on, Lieutenant, as you would charge a regiment of the English---come on ! With swords in their hands, men are equal! Lunge, sir, at your pleasure, and think you are fighting for Louise !

div.stage: [Alphonse, in fury, makes several lunges. Latour parries them all, and eventually disarms him.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: (raising Alphonse's sword with his, and presenting it) Take your life, Sir. I have no present intention of banning, or even of insulting you. But you will go to Mons. Damiron's house, and plead my cause with the haughty planter and his daughter. You will succeed, I know, for you can tell them, in addition to the argument, you will find in your desk, that I am, above all things, (with strong intention) an excellent master to my female slaves. Adieu, Sir, we shall meet at the ball. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Fool! miserable fool!—duped—defeated—disgraced ! —Louise, Louise, how dearly do I pay for having deceived you. —Miscreant! But words are idle. I have no course but that chalked out for me by him. At any price, she must be saved ! [Exit.

div.stage: Drop descends.

div.head: Scene I.—Near Damiron's House. Front Grooves.
div.stage: Alphonse is crossing the stage, moodily, when Bellona follows him rapidly.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Lieutenant de Nyon !

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Do not stop me. I am in no mood to be crossed.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But for a moment.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I have not a moment.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You will not lose time by hearing me.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Quickly, then—especially if you come to speak of—of her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No, no, I have nothing more to urge to you upon that subject. An inward voice is speaking far more bitterly to you, than I could dare to do.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Aye—bitterly, indeed!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But I have reason to believe that something is about to happen, for which you would do well to prepare. I have been into the town, and I find a strange agitation amongst the inhabitants.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: And the cause ?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I cannot ascertain it; but it is said that a strange communication has been made by telegraph from a ship now in the offing—a ship which reports itself direct from France. She is supposed to bring important despatches from government.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Mere rumour.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
But rumour very widely circulated. The inhabitants couple it with the sudden arrival of our troops, and are apparently expecting some event hostile to their interests. They
scowl at our soldiers; and I myself have received several insults and menaces, in my search for you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: You hare done well to make it. I have an errand at Damiron's, which admits of no delay. That discharged, I will go down to the barracks. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: An errand at Damiron's! What errand can he have there ? His servants declare they heard the clash of swords in the garden, and that M. Latour came out, as flushed and haughty as if he had just won a battle. Yet Alphonse is the best swordsman in the regiment, except that preternatural coxcomb, Hyacinthe St. Emilion, who swears he was born with a foil and mask. All this is mysterious, and I must clear it up. I must see after my ally, and then I'll go to Damiron's myself. and question them all. They'll be impertinent, perhaps, but I think I carry rather too many guns for them, and, indeed, for the world in general. [ Exit.

div.head: Scene II. — An Apartment at Damiron's.
div.stage: Enter Virginie.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I am perfectly ashamed of myself for feeling so happy when I recollect that the only reason is my thinking that I am likely to be married—married—and married to Hyacinthe. We won't stay here, that I am resolved upon. No, I will make him take me away to France. Dear, dear France! beautiful as this island is, I can never, never learn to love it as a home.

lg.head: Song. Poetry by Shirley Brooks. Music by Alexander Lee.
lg.l: Waves of gold, in music breaking
Foam around our rosy Isle,
Here the Day-God, early waking,
Wears for her his warmest smile.
Winds are ours, with every motion
Gently wafting odours by ;
E'en the mighty heart of Ocean
Seems to heave with passion's sigh.
Yet, though fair the home may be, '
Tis no home, no home for me.
There's a land, whose castles hoary
O'er her aged forests frown,
Where a thousand years of glory
Through her bannered aisles look down.
Where my sires, in marble sleeping,
Hallow scenes they guarded long;
While their fame, in minstrel keeping,
Still survives to swell the song.
Far away, o'er many a sea,
There's the home, the home for me.

sp.p: So then, papa, M. de Nyon, after all, disposed of this poor girl as coldly, and unhesitatingly, as if he had never cared about her.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p:
Quite. You surely do not censure him for that. He
had committed an error, and he repaired it as soon as possible.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Far too soon. I wish he had shown more feeling for her.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: For a slave ? Your sentiments, young lady, have taken a very sudden turn. This morning you had no such sympathies.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: That is true, papa. But (aside) this morning I had not learned what love means, and now it is teaching me to feel even for a slave.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: I hope M. St. Emilion, who seems hardly to have left you for a moment since he arrived, has not been embuing you with any such folly. Remember the cards you hold, and the game you have to play.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Yes, sir. There are no hearts in the pack—(aside) ah ! here's Hyacinthe again.

div.stage: Enter Hyacinthe St. Emilion.

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: You see I profit by your kind permission to make myself at home among you, my dear M. Damiron.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Delighted, of course (aside), but I could wish Alphonse would propose, and then I should have an excuse for shutting the door in his face.

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: And the preparations for the ball, Mademoiselle?— all made, I suppose. You will not forget to place me very high, and very often, in your list of partners. I don't boast, but I think you will approve my dancing.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: We must pay particular attention to so distinguished a performer. I can't promise for the first place in the list, for that is of course reserved for M. de Nyon, who gives the ball.

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: Ah ! that's all right—all etiquette—but the second, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: And for the second dance I am half engaged ; but we shall see if my partner claims me.

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: May I ask the wretch's name ? I hate him by anticipation.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Monsieur Latour.

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: The brown man. Oh, decidedly I trust he will not appear. We may—differ.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I hope not.

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: Then you take some interest in my destiny ? Happy Hyacinthe !

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Why not suppose I take some in the destiny of Monsieur Latour ?

sp.speaker: Hyac.
