sp.p: This time it is my turn to hope not. (In a lower voice) I adore you, Virginie : and I will run anybody through who looks at you !

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Hush! hush! or papa –

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: I'll begin with him, if he interferes.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Surely there is Alphonse coming up the path ?

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: Yes—it is. Except myself, there is nobody in the regiment can put his clothes on so well as Alphonse. But he does not look very brilliant now. Let us meet him, and tell him he's a disgrace to society. Allow me –

div.stage: [He takes her hand, and they go off with a playful formality.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: I shall stop this boy-and-girl affair before mischief is done. Aha! they meet him. What are they saying? He is motioning them to go to the aviary. He comes up. I wish he would take it into his head to propose for Virginie to-day.Enter Alphonse.Ah ! my young friend ! But you look quite melancholy and dispirited.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: My spirits are not very buoyant this afternoon, certainly, sir.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Thinking of the little scene of the morning, perhaps ? That recollection will soon wear away.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Never! (With a struggle) But, Monsieur Damiron, one must not allow feelings to interfere with business.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: A most proper remark, Monsieur Alphonse. And what business have you now to transact ? Nothing disagreeable, I trust ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: It is of a kind usually considered interesting.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Well, my friend, do I understand that you intend to confide it to me ? [They sit.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: You are deeply concerned in it.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: 'Gad, if my hope should be realized ! (Aloud) I am all attention.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Will you, then, allow me to ask whether you have formed any definite design for the disposal of the hand of Mdlle. Damiron ?

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: A father's hopes, my dear Alphonse, will sometimes ——. But, to answer you more explicitly, Mdlle. Damiron is disengaged.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I have recently, my dear Monsieur Damiron, been looking over my papers, securities, and so forth. I find, among other things—we are speaking merely for form's sake (Damiron nods and smiles)—that you, sir, and my late father had various transactions between you.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: We had, my boy—we had. I was not at all times rich, and he materially assisted me. I may safely say to you, in confidence, that your desk contains all I have in the world. I know I may safely confess that to you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I may, perhaps, infer that, presuming a proposal for the honour of Miss Damiron's hand were submitted to her and to you, there is no reason why it should fail of approval ?

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: I do not think (smiling) that Monsieur de Nyon is likely to suggest a very ineligible match for Virginie.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Suppose, Sir, that on the wedding-day, instead of asking a dowry with the bride, the intended husband should present her father with all his mortgages and securities, cancelled and destroyed.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: I can hardly misunderstand you, Monsieur de Nyon as there is nobody but yourself who has the power to do what you mention. Such a son-in-law shall meet the most favourable reception from Virginie and myself. (Aside) Settled !

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I can offer you a son-in-law upon those terms.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: I accept him and them.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Then I may tell the suitor that he will be received whenever he pleases ?

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Tell him ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Yes; I have promised him the earliest possible account of this interview.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: We are misunderstanding one another, Sir; and yet it seems hardly possible. This proposal, is it not made on your own account?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: On mine, Sir ?

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: On yours, Sir !

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: It is not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Not? Sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Did I even mention my own name in opening the subject, Monsieur Damiron?

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Did you—did you—did you ? but didn't you—didn't you make me believe you meant yourself ? Who else, Sir, who else could I suppose you meant?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I know not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: And pray, Sir, (struggling with his rage) for whom have you done me the honour to obtain my promise ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: One who has known Mdlle. Damiron far longer than myself, and who declares that he loves her—well.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Damn'd kind of him, Sir, damn'd kind ! And his name, Sir, unless you are ashamed of it?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Monsieur Antony Latour.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: The Creole ? Don't say you mean him.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: It is for him I make the offer, Monsieur Damiron, and for him I am willing to make, also, the sacrifice I have promised.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: So, so! Hark ye, Monsieur de Nyon. For the sake of your father I will not order my servants to turn you into the street; but get out of my house, Sir, instantly, and take with you this message to the rascal who has --Heaven knows how—prevailed upon a gheintleman's son to offer such an insult to a gentleman. Tell that if, in addition to the bait you offer, his brown carcase were weighed against gold, and the gold laid on my carpet in exchange for my child's hand, I would spurn it, Sir, spurn it—and spit upon it—as I do on him and his offer— and, but for your father's sake –

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.stage: (who has borne the earlier part of this speech with composure, gradually becomes excited, and at last springs up, and interrupts, in a voice of thunder)
sp.p: Stop, Sir !—for your own sake, stop!

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: I comprehend your menace, Sir, well. It befits the errand on which you come—the vagabond for whom you plead. But I care not, Sir—use your power—seize, sell all I have in the world—end my life of industry and struggle in penury and shame—drive me and my child to the street, to starvation— but dare not to imagine that the fear of all you can do will induce me to debase my house by stooping to herd with your Creole. (With bitter irony) Such are the tactics of a soldier of France.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Monsieur. Damiron, if you knew—if you could judge—nay, I will reveal to you

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir—nothing. Take your own course.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Your feelings, as compared with mine

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Spare me the comparison, sir. Listen. I was over-hasty on one point. The ball in my house to-night is yours. It must take place—the guests are bidden, and the hospitality of the Isle of France must sustain no slur. You will attend ; and, as far as appearances go, no one shall suspect what has passed between us. But, as the last guest departs, you will attend him to the door—and will never return. Adieu, Monsieur de Nyon.

div.stage: [Bows formally, and exit.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: As I anticipated, bribe and threat alike derided, and the bitterest scorn poured upon him who employed them. Louise! Louise! what new expedient to save her from the fate to which I have so madly consigned her? By this hour, long ago, I had pictured her free and happy; and now she is the victim of a revengeful wretch, who ——. But there is no time for words. I will seek him again; and if gold—threats— fail, this time my sword may do me better service.

div.stage: [Exit hastily.

div.head: Scene III.—Apartment in the house of Latour, meagrely furnished. Enter Latour, bringing in Louise.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: This, Mademoiselle, is my house — your home. When I have reminded you that it is the house of your master, I am sure I shall need no further argument to ensure your obedience.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: Spare me! spare me !

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Why this terror? Pray be calm. Do you think that I am a wild beast, to injure you without cause ?

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: Why, oh ! why have I fallen into your hands ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: That you can demand of your late owner and lover, who saw fit to sell you to me.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: Oh, Heavens! But it is (vehemently) false—false! There is some atrocious juggle of which I am the victim ! He —he willingly expose me to such a doom—he ? I will not believe it!

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Yet you pleaded so earnestly to himself, in my presence, that even I was half inclined to renounce my bargain.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: I did. Yes, I prayed in abjectness and terror, and he refused to hear me. And yet—while I clasped his arm, when I sank at his knee, I could see the convulsive struggle of his frame—I could see the cold drops upon his brow. He suffered even more than I. I know it—I swear it! Love can never read love wrongly.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Yet you are here—mine !

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p:
I am ! I am the victim of some dark, foul plot, which I understand not. But let what will fall upon me, I
will never believe that my doom has come from his hand. He has loved me—he loves me still !

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I trust so, or my power ends. (Aloud) Louise, he does!

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: Ah! you tell me so ? Blessings on you—blessings on you ! I forgive you all, so that you assure me of that !

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: He loves you, and has never ceased to love you. He imagined himself wroth with you for concealing from him that you were a slave ; but that thought vanished with the hour of its birth. I tell you he is yours—and you are mine.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: So be it. I can die; but I cannot doubt.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Die! no—that would inconvenience me materially. Enter Bellona, running.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha! Then they were right! They told me you had dared to take her from her chamber, and drag her to your abominable house ! Oh I how lucky for you that I was not there at the time! Wouldn't I ! Never mind, my child ! (Caressingly to Louise.)

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: Dear Bellona! I have heard such words of comfort since I came here.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Not from him. I should say that shop was quite out of comfort, and very uncertain when any would come in.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: Yes; he has told me what I would give worlds to hear.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What ? Not that he is likely to be hanged ? That's too good to be true.

div.stage: [Latour smiles contemptuously.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: Bellona, he has told me that Alphonse loves me !

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I could have told you that ; so you owe him nothing. I have seen Monsieur de Nyon.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: On his way to Monsieur Damiron's ?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes, on his way to Monsieur Damiron's?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: That is well.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh, he looked so melancholy. He has been cheated in some way, however, and I have a great guess at the rascal who did it.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: It was myself.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I meant you, on my honour.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I have no wish to give Louise needless pain—she rather deserves my pity—she, like myself, is of a proscribed race.

sp.speaker: Bel.
Latour.
sp.p: Silence ! I have told the girl that she is loved. I tell her also that she would never have been sold to me (Louise listens intently) but for De Nyon's anxiety to liberate her from slavery. I bought her to effect this, which, he could not do. I promised to set her free.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And why, then, Monsieur Latour, don't you keep your promise, if you please?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Because it suits me better to break it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You audacious, cheating, swindling, deceiving, venomous, abominable, treacherous, good for nothing –

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Creole.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes, in saying that, you say all the rest.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: So thinks the Isle of France ; it would be uncivil to prove it in the wrong.

sp.speaker: Louise.
sp.p: Let him do his worst; Henri, I mean, Monsieur Alphonse, is true!

div.stage: Enter Bokes.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: You here, France?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: What brings you over my threshold :

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Eh? Your threshold ! Nevermind. It's not (looking round) so charming a place, or furnished so elegantly, as to make one anxious to come here for nothing.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: What do you want ?

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Well, since you're so pressing, I want four thousand francs. Shall I give you a receipt ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: You know well that you will not get the money.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Do I ? I happen to know that I shall.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I'm glad of it. In the meantime, go away.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: When I please. In the meantime, as those chairs were bought with my money, and as that table was bought with my money, and as that sofa was bought with my money, I should think I might take the liberty of using which of 'em I please.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Insolent –

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: No, not as you may say, insolent. I speak my mind, and I've bought the right to do it. I didn't ask you to have my money, you know ; you asked me.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I now ask you to get out of my house. (In fury) You will make me forget myself.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Oh, that's nothing new to me. I don't mind that a bit.

div.stage: [Bellona laughs tauntingly. This enrages Latour.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Bokes, don't force me to turn you out of the house !

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Well, I don't—if I was the debtor, and you was the creditor, and all the things here were yours, I might, by being saucy.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.stage: (seizes him and thrusts him roughly out)
sp.p: Thank yourself for this ! (returns) an insolent reptile !

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Now, Antony Latour, you have ruined yourself! As long as you kept a civil tongue, I bore a deal from you—but now you've chosen to lay hands on me, I'll never forgive you ; and I'll ruin you, as sure as I stand here ! I'll ruin you —I'll ruin you—I'll ruin you! [ Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I know that little man well. He has a great knack of keeping his word, whatever you may think of the accomplishment.

div.stage: [A servant announces " M. de Nyon." Latour starts—Bellona looks delighted.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I do not wish to see him. Say, with my compliments, that I am dressing for his ball, and that I will then hear what he has to say. (Exit servant.) You observe, Louise, that he is completely at my command.

div.stage: [Noise.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes, I should say that noise looks like it.

div.stage: Enter Alphonse, hastily.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Such a message to me—how dare—(sees Louise) Louise here !

div.stage: [Louise is about to rush to him, when Latour raises his hand forbiddingly—she stops.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: To my arms, Louise ! (with great warmth)

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: What! against her master's orders?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: And if I strike that—that master dead upon the spot.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: That his property (pointing at her) may devolve upon his cousin, Jerome, of the Isle of Bourbon (all said slowly) a worthy man, but rather violent in his habits.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Villain !

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Yet you would recommend me as your friend's husband. How speeds my wooing ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: How should it speed ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I comprehend. We may mend it at your ball. Adieu, M. de Nyon. Till after the ball you have nothing to fear for her (points to Louise).

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: After, nor before, nor at any time, Alphonse, while I have life and breath ! I love her for your sake, and for her own, and I tell her, and I tell you, and I tell that copper-coloured creature there, that I will never leave her, from this moment, until she is happy and free, and ready to become your wife. Perhaps that may be sooner than he imagines—but, whether or not, I am her friend, and wherever she goes, I go with her; and whatever she does, I help her to do. So let him take care what he gives her to do, and how he behaves to her while with him; for the very first moment that he does or says anything I disapprove of, I will declare war upon him in the name of France, tear his eyes out of his head, set fire to his abominable house, and carry away Louise under cover of the smoke !

div.stage: [Takes Louise by the hand, and exits with her.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: The ball decides her destiny and mine, Monsieur de Nyon. Till then --[ Exit.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: It does, indeed ; for I will bear this no longer. My regiment will be under arms to be ready for this apprehended disturbance, and, if there be no better way, I will tear her from this place, convey her to the Fort, and behind a line of glittering bayonets, in the hands of my gallant troop, she may defy all the slaveholders in the world ! [Exit.

div.stage: Scene The Last.—A magnificent ball-room in the house of Damiron, with columns clustered with green leaves and flowers. In the back ground is seen the sea, with stars shining through a colonnade. Couches, chairs, &c. Music. Short general dance.
Enter Damiron.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: And all this display is perhaps for the last time. A single day may see me a houseless beggar. The revenge of the Creole is insatiable, and he will doubtless avail himself of his strange influence over this young man to ruin and disgrace me. But were the scene to occur again, I would repeat the words used. Virginie to him ! As I gaze on her, (Virginie is seen coming down) the very thought is profanation !

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Alone, papa ! That is well, for I want to ask you a favour.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: What, my darling ?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: As you tell me I am not to marry Monsieur Latour, and as Monsieur de Nyon will not marry me—if you please, may I marry Monsieur St. Emilion ?

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Has he asked you the question ?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Hm—no—I told him not to ask me until I had spoken to you, as I should be exceedingly sorry to refuse him.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Let him speak to me, then, in the first instance.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: But don't be offended at his levity, papa, it's only manner—in reality, he's as honourable as Bayard, and as brave as Dumouriez.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: So he has told you, I presume.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Oh ! I know he is—nobody can deceive me.

div.stage: [Servant announces— "His Excellency the Governor !" Enter the Governor, General MaLartic, followed by a numerous suite with cocked hats and feathers. As Damiron comes forward to receive the Governor, Hyacinthe comes on, as from apartment at the side.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: (salutes Virginie and Damiron) M. Damiron, your magnificent apartments look to-night more brilliant than ever.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: I fear any increased attraction your Excellency may see is derived from no merit of mine, but from the presence of so many gay soldiers of France.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: You have the merit of assembling them, at least, M. Damiron. But do I see Lieutenant de Nyon here?

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: De Nyon will be here instantly, your Excellency. In consequence of certain reports— (Governor makes him a sign of caution) with which I need not trouble your Excellency, he thought it desirable, at the last moment, to visit the barracks, and see that all is in readiness.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I duly appreciate his zeal and forethought.

div.stage: [Bokes enters, dressed in great splendour. Damiron advances, not recognising him, but the moment he makes him out, seems mortified, as the Governor is looking at them.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: How d'e do, M. Damiron ? Do me the favour to present me to the Governor.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: You, Bokes? Impossible!

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Then I shall present myself.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Be quiet, pray! Such a thing would be outrageous !

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: But why not ? Have I not taken pains to do you and your party honour ? Look at me, sir. Is there anybody in the room dressed like this?

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Not precisely, I confess. But the Governor is fastidious.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: He'll like me, I can tell you. Besides, it is necessary that I should know him, because I shall want him presently.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Want the Governor !

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Yes. Which is he ?

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: That. But if you have any regard for me, do nothing absurd.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Sir, you have invited me to your house, and I beg to state that I shall behave myself as such, Fear nothing. An exciting scene, Governor.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Very.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: There ! I knew we should be friends. But it will be more exciting presently, Governor.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Agreeably, I hope.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: To some people, very—to others, less so. But you have nothing to apprehend, nothing.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: You take a weight off my mind, sir.

div.stage: Enter Alphonse, handsomely dressed.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Ah! there's Monsieur de Nyon. I wonder where the other is ?

div.stage: [Alphonse passes Damiron and Virginie, bowing to each, the salute being formal—then goes to the Governor, who receives him very courteously.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: The vessel has not yet come in, I presume, Lieutenant ?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Her despatches will be in your Excellency's hand in half an hour.

div.stage: Enter Latour, richly dressed.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: There he is. Now let him look out.

div.stage: [Latour approaches the Governor's seat, and bows, the Governor returns the salute slightly—he then looks round, but nobody seems anxious to recognise him.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: The same cold reception as usual, but my time is coming. M. Damiron's plumes will soon be plucked by de Nyon, or de Nyon's fate shall be worse still! Why do I waste time? (Latour advances.) The honour of Mademoiselle Damiron's hand ?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I fear I am engaged.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: To me, if I remember aright.

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: No, to me!

div.stage: [He in about to lead her away, when Latour attempts to touch her hand.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Surely, this morning I ventured to ask—

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: The engagement is to me, sir, I repeat!
These half-bloods can never take an answer. [Takes her to place in dance.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: M. St. Emilion!

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: When the dance is over, sir, you may speak to me!

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: And I will, fear not!

div.stage: [Latour leans at the side, Bokes watching him.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Now the rooms are as full as they are likely to be, so now's the time, (calls) Governor Malartic !

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: How can I please M. Bokes?

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Might I ask your Excellency to step this way ?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: The request is so unusual, that I think we must grant it.

div.stage: [He comes down, followed by a great number of the guests. Latour looks on.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: The liberty is awful that I have taken, Governor. It makes my hair stand on end to think of it!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Do not think of it, sir, I pray, Only explain it.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: This dreadful little Jew will be my death !

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Will your Excellency condescend to cast your eyes in the direction I am about to point out ? (points at Latour, who draws himself up) The prospect is no ways inviting, perhaps, but very instructive.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: You will take care, sir, that you allow no jest to become disagreeable.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: He ain't thin skinn'd, Governor, though I see he looks as if he wanted to sneak away. Look at him, and observe how fine he is dressed. Yet he has no money, not a sou, and is nothing more nor better than a common swindler.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Your Excellency will probably order this mad little creature to be put out of the house.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: His Excellency won't do nothing of the sort. His Excellency won't take a leaf out of your book, I can tell you. You may do such things, ill treating an honest man, who asks for his own, but the Governor's a cut above such swindling and bullying, or two cuts, for that matter! [Guests smile.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Any complaint of this sort, M. Bokes, should be reserved for the proper place.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: And so it would, your heavenly Excellency, but there's worse behind. This fellow entrapped M. Alphonse there, into selling him a slave, on condition of setting her free, and now he has got her, he vows to keep her, and threatens her with all sorts of humiliations, to break the heart of M. de Nyon, who's in love with her.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: What, why is this subject brought forward here?

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Because here's the right place for it. What's the use of being mealy mouthed ? I ain't. There's the Governor, and here's all the parties—make an end of the thing at once.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Is this exposure from revenge, M. Damiron, for a certain honour I intended you ?

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: No, sir, contempt is my only revenge for any insult from you.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Monsieur de Nyon may feel it necessary to change your opinion of me.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: De Nyon. Ha ! (reflects) I see it now.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I am glad of it, M. Damiron.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I had hoped, gentlemen, that one intimation of my wish would have been sufficient. I must now desire that this subject be instantly dropped.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Now he means earnest. I daren't say no more. I've done all I could to oblige my ally, France, and now she must be patient, and watch the turn of the market.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I am accustomed to insult, your Excellency—my colour justifies it, and prevents its expiation.

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: We have no such prejudices in France.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Ha! coxcomb!

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: No noise, if you mean anything beside noise.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Dare you ?

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: Dare—this from a demi-savage to a Parisian !

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: The gardens are large—the moon is bright.

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: How romantic—follow me, but cautiously, if you really mean fighting.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Unless my sword arm have lost its skill since the morning, in five minutes there will be one fool the fewer. [Hyacinthe and Latour go out.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: I think he won't forget that exposure in a hurry, and that's nothing to what I'll do for him yet. I'll teach him to keep his hands off folks!

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: What a strange net has been spread for poor De Nyon. I must forgive him. But the worst of it is, he is not out of the meshes.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Papa, have you seen M. Hyacinthe ? He was here a few moments ago. I want him to stand up with me in a minuet.

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: He cannot be far off. Alphonse!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Dami.
sp.p: Nay, I have thought over your conduct, and now that I have heard something of its cause, of which you must tell me more, we shall perhaps know one another better.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: If anything could give me pleasure while that villain Latour –

div.stage: Enter Bellona.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Everybody's pardon, but death's the matter!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Death !

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: It soon will be, at least.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: But whose death, girl ?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: M. Hyacinthe and M. Latour have been out into the garden to fight. I saw them begin.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: And why not have called for help ?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: There was no time, sir. They are both splendid swordsmen. They lost not a moment—their swords crossed but three times, and M. Latour fell. They are bringing him in, but he can't live many minutes. [Great sensation.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Hyacinthe has deprived me of the task I proposed to myself, when Louise should be free.

sp.speaker: Bokes.
sp.p: Killed my debtor? What right had he to do that ? I shall lose all chance of my four thousand francs.

div.stage:
[Latour is brought in wounded, and placed in a chair.
He is brought from the back and supported by two officers. His coat and waistcoat are off, and his shirt is stained with blood.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: M. Latour, this is a most unhappy affair.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: It is so, sir. Allow me to recommend M. Hyacinthe for promotion. He is the best fencer with whom I ever engaged—he ran me through with great skill.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Have surgeons been summoned ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: They are useless—I am dying, and I acquit my adversary of any unfair dealing. The Creole can be just –

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: At such a moment –

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: True! Your Excellency as chief officer of this colony, will now hear, and will hereafter bear witness to the few words in which I shall make my will.

div.stage: [They all attend.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Proceed, sir. (to an officer) Make a note.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: I have no property in the world, except a slave— (Alphonse comes forward) Louise Fauriel, purchased of that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Shall she come in ?

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Ah ! is she here ?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Did I not say, I would never forsake her ? She came with me. I will bring her. [ Exit.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Aye, do, then my revenge will be perfect. (Bellona re-enters with Louise) Stand here, Louise, near me, I command you. I am your master still. (Alphonse places himself near Louise—Latour smiles.) This slave I give and bequeath to my cousin, M. Jerome, of the Isle of Bourbon. I described his character to you, M. de Nyon.

div.stage: [Officer writes.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: This in your dying hour!

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Yes, what could sweeten such an hour so much as a parting act of vengeance ? Louise, you hear your doom !

div.stage: [Louise buries her face in her hands.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Stay, there is protection yet for the helpless. This person, (pointing to Bokes) a money lender, under a document which he holds, is entitled to whatever property M. Latour may have at any time. Surely the slave becomes his, your Excellency.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: If the document be correct, undoubtedly.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Then, Louise, dearest, you are safe—your destiny is in my hands—you shall be free in an hour! [Embraces her.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Hardly. But speaking becomes painful. If your Excellency will condescend to listen. (Whispers.)

div.stage: [All look intent.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: That, if true, alters the case once more.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What—how—why ?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: This person is an alien, and is incapable of owning a slave.

div.stage: [Despair in the features of Bellona, Alphonse, and Louise.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Could you—ha ! ha !—imagine that I had forgotten the Jew? Louise, I repeat it, you are a bequest to my cruel cousin.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Never ! She shall not go !

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Even against a Creole, the law will hardly allow robbery.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: This person has an absolute right, and it must be respected. (Great disturbance, and shouting.) What is this disturbance?

div.stage: [Renewed shouting. Enter an officer, with despatches, which he gives the Governor.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: The despatches from the vessel, direct from Paris!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Good Heavens, we shall have a revolution in the island !

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Ha! (raising himself).

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Lieutenant de Nyon, bring up your regiment, and surround this house, before the people hear the news, and the uproar commences.

div.stage: [March heard. Hyacinthe enters at the head of soldiers, who draw up at back.

sp.speaker: Hyac.
sp.p: I have ventured to anticipate your Excellency's order?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: So far you have done well. But (pointing to Latour), consider yourself under arrest.

sp.speaker: Latour.
sp.p: Might one hear the last news from Paris ? I should like to take it with me.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Listen, all. It concerns nearly all present; and you, my poor girl, more than all. (All attend.) "By a decree of the National Convention of France, slavery is henceforth abolished in all her colonies." [Latour falls dead.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Mine—mine for ever— Louise !

div.stage: [Shout —waving of plumes, handkerchiefs, &c. As the applause ceases, Bellona comes down to the front.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The day for claptraps is gone by, and a wiser rule has left the moral to be learned from the play, rather than to be pointed by the actor. But may we be permitted to remind those who have sympathised in the fortunes of our poor slave girl, that at this very hour there exist, in other countries, speaking our own language, thousands of maidens as young, as fair, as loving, and as liable to be bought and sold like beasts of the field. We can perhaps do but little towards lightening their fate; but may we not remember, with a thankful pride, that our own is cast in a land where (with all its faults) the chain is unknown — where God's image is unsullied by the brand of slavery ?

div.stage: (Curtain falls.)
